description: From Old French troubleus, corresponding to trouble +â€Ž -ous.

adjectives.description: troublous (comparative more troublous, superlative most troublous)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Of a liquid: thick, muddy, full of sediment.
(now archaic or literary) Causing trouble; troublesome, vexatious.
examples: the mystery, the pervasive melancholy, the vaguely troublous forecast and retrospect which possess the mind in contemplating this sequestered spot, unhallowed save by the sense of a common humanity [...]
